ElementName_en: Log10 of number density of atmosphere
Log10 of number density of ozone
Total electron count per square metre
Maximum image spectral component before normalization
Mole fraction of atmospheric constituent/pollutant in dry air
Atmospheric path delay in satellite signal
Estimated error in atmospheric path delay
Difference in path delays for limb views at extremes of scan
Estimated error in path delay difference
Component of zenith path delay due to water vapour
Path delay due to neutral atmosphere (see Note 10)
Note_en: (10) 0 15 038 is the delay of an electromagnetic wave in the neutral atmosphere as compared to undisturbed propagation in vacuum. The delay due to ionized gases in the ionosphere is not covered, hence "neutral atmosphere". The delay in meters is the time delay multiplied by the vacuum speed of light.

ElementName_en: Estimated error in neutral atmosphere path delay
Log10 of number density of aerosol particles with diameter greater than 5 nm
Log10 of number density of aerosol particles with diameter greater than 14 nm
Log10 of number density of aerosol particles with diameter between 0.25 and 2.5 um
Zenith path delay due to neutral atmosphere (see Note 11)
Note_en: (11) 0 15 079 is the hypothetical path delay with the transmitter, e.g. GNSS satellite, in the zenith of the receiver.

ElementName_en: Estimated error in neutral atmosphere zenith path delay
Wet path delay due to neutral atmosphere (see Note 12)
Note_en: (12) 0 15 081 is the contribution of atmospheric water vapour to the path delay.
(16) 015082 is the amount of atmospheric water vapour integrated along the signal path.

ElementName_en: GNSS derived neutral atmosphere gradient (see Note 17)
Note_en: (17) 0 15 083 is the gradient (east-west or north-south) of the neutral atmosphere estimated by the GNSS processing.
(18) 015084 Non-modelled contribution to the path delay estimated by the least squares adjustment of GNSS path delays.
(15) 0 15 085 is the excess delay due to multi-path effects which needs to be removed from the estimated path delay.

(19) A mapping function is an empirical projection of the zenith delay onto the path delay: Path delay = mapping function * zenith delay. It is a dimensionless real number greater than or equal to one. Different mapping functions are used for the wet and hydrostatic contributions to the delay and for the GNSS gradients.

ElementName_en: Zenith path delay due to neutral hydrostatic atmosphere (see Note 13)
Note_en: (13) 015089 is the contribution of the (almost) dry atmosphere to the zenith path delay as expressed by the hydrostatic equation.

ElementName_en: Path delay due to neutral hydrostatic atmosphere (see Note 14)
Note_en: (14) 015090 is the zenith path delay due to the neutral hydrostatic atmosphere mapped onto the signal path.
